## Why ranks?
When groups are skewed or have outliers/unequal variances, rank-based tests are robust because they use order, not raw scale.

```r
set.seed(1)
library(rankcomp)

# toy data (fast)
A <- rnorm(15, 0.3, 1)
B <- rnorm(16, 0.0, 1)
C <- rnorm(14, 0.3, 1)
x <- c(A,B,C)
g <- factor(rep(c("A","B","C"), c(length(A),length(B),length(C))))

## 1) All-pairs (Wilcoxon + adjusted p-values)
pairs_tab <- pairwise_rank_sum(x, g, method = "holm")
pairs_tab

## 2) Interpretable effects (AUC)
eff_tab <- np_effect_size(x, g, measure = "auc", ci = TRUE, nboot = 200, seed = 1)
eff_tab

## 3) "Close enough?" via equivalence on AUC
eq_tab <- equivalence_np(x, g, delta = 0.05, measure = "auc",
                         alternative = "equivalence", nboot = 200, seed = 1)
eq_tab
